name: Acetaminophen
summary: Acetaminophen is a non-opioid analgesic and antipyretic used to treat mild to moderate pain and fever. It has minimal anti-inflammatory properties and is often used as a first-line analgesic in pediatrics.
indications: Mild to moderate pain (e.g., headache, musculoskeletal pain)
Fever in pediatric and adult patients
sideEffects: Generally well tolerated at therapeutic doses
Hepatotoxicity with overdose or in severe liver disease
cautions: Avoid exceeding total daily dose from all sources (including combination products)
Monitor for unintentional overdose from multiple acetaminophen-containing products

compatibility.iv: Check institutional IV compatibility guide; often compatible with common maintenance fluids.
compatibility.oral: Compatible with food; can be given with small amounts of fluid.
compatibility.other: Avoid excessive alcohol intake due to increased hepatotoxicity risk.

standardDose: 10–15 mg/kg PO/PR Q4–6H PRN (maximum daily dose per institutional guideline).

name: Ibuprofen
summary: Ibuprofen is an NSAID used for pain with an inflammatory component and for fever. It works by inhibiting prostaglandin synthesis.
indications: Mild to moderate pain with inflammatory component (e.g., musculoskeletal injuries)
Fever in pediatric and adult patients
sideEffects: Risk of GI bleeding with prolonged use or high doses
Renal impairment in dehydration or pre-existing kidney disease
cautions: Avoid in significant renal impairment or dehydration
Use with caution in history of GI ulcer/bleeding
Avoid late in pregnancy unless specifically ordered

compatibility.iv: Refer to institutional compatibility guidelines for IV formulations.
compatibility.oral: Give with food or milk to reduce GI upset.
compatibility.other: Avoid concurrent NSAIDs unless specifically directed.

standardDose: 5–10 mg/kg PO Q6–8H PRN (maximum daily dose per institutional guideline).

name: Hydromorphone
summary: Hydromorphone is a strong opioid analgesic used to treat moderate to severe pain. It requires careful monitoring for sedation and respiratory depression.
cautions: Monitor respiratory rate, sedation score, and oxygen saturation
Use with caution in respiratory compromise (e.g., asthma, sleep apnea)
Avoid combination with other CNS depressants unless closely monitored

compatibility.iv: Refer to institutional IV opioid compatibility chart.
compatibility.oral: Swallow oral forms as directed; do not crush controlled-release formulations.
compatibility.other: Use appropriate opioid lockout intervals with PCA devices.

standardDose: Example only: 0.01–0.02 mg/kg IV Q3–4H PRN (follow institutional protocol; not for real-world prescribing).

name: Clindamycin
summary: Clindamycin is an antibiotic with good activity against many Gram-positive organisms and anaerobes. It is often used for skin, soft tissue, and some ENT infections, including penicillin-allergic patients when appropriate.
indications: Treatment option in certain penicillin-allergic patients (per local guidelines)
cautions: Monitor for new-onset or worsening diarrhea
Use cautiously in patients with history of colitis
Ensure appropriate indication based on local resistance patterns

compatibility.iv: Check IV compatibility guide; requires appropriate dilution and infusion rate.
compatibility.oral: Can be given with or without food; may reduce GI upset if taken with food.
compatibility.other: Educate families to report significant diarrhea promptly.

standardDose: Dose and frequency depend on infection type and route; follow institutional pediatric guideline.

name: Cefazolin
summary: Cefazolin is a first-generation cephalosporin commonly used for skin, soft tissue, and some surgical prophylaxis indications. It covers many Gram-positive organisms.
indications: Selected bone and joint infections (per protocol)
cautions: Use with caution in patients with serious penicillin allergy (cross-reactivity possible)

compatibility.iv: Refer to institutional IV antibiotic compatibility chart.
compatibility.oral: Not typically used orally; primarily IV.
compatibility.other: Verify timing if given in relation to surgery for prophylaxis.

standardDose: Typical pediatric IV dosing is weight-based; follow institutional guideline for mg/kg and frequency.

name: Gentamicin
summary: Gentamicin is an aminoglycoside antibiotic used for serious Gram-negative infections and in combination regimens. It requires therapeutic drug monitoring due to nephrotoxicity and ototoxicity risk.
indications: Combination therapy for certain neonatal or complicated infections
cautions: Requires careful dosing and level monitoring (peaks/troughs or AUC per protocol)
Adjust dose and interval in renal impairment
Avoid concurrent nephrotoxic drugs when possible

compatibility.iv: Check IV compatibility; may be incompatible with some beta-lactams in same line.
compatibility.oral: Not used orally for systemic effect.
compatibility.other: Ensure families understand that hearing tests or level monitoring may be required.

standardDose: Weight-based IV dosing with intervals based on age and renal function; follow institutional protocol.
